did.unittitle: Stevens Thomson Mason Papers 1827-1842
did.abstract: First governor of Michigan; correspondence, drafts of letters to Andrew Jackson and to Secretary of State John Forsyth; draft of his inaugural address, 1838 and of other messages to the Legislature; topics covered include the Toledo War and the dispute arising from his appointment as Secretary of the Michigan Territory.

bioghist.p: Stevens Thomson Mason was born in Virginia (October 27, 1811) and educated in Kentucky where his father had emigrated in 1812. In 1830, his father, John Mason, was appointed secretary of the Territory of Michigan by President Andrew Jackson. He resigned a year later and left for Texas and Mexico perhaps on a mission for the president. In his place, Jackson named the nineteen year old Stevens Mason to the vacant secretariat, taking his oath of office on July 25, 1831. As secretary Mason was also ex-officio governor during the absence of then Governor Porter. With Porter's death, July 6, 1834, Mason became acting governor. Here he led the movement for statehood and prosecuted the boundary dispute with Ohio. He was elected governor in his own right on November 3, 1835, serving two terms, leaving office on January 7, 1840. His administration was plagued by financial difficulties brought on by the Panic of 1837 bringing to a halt many internal improvements projects that had been anticipated. Mason did not run for a third term, instead retired from politics, moving to New York where he practiced law. He died January 4, 1843.

scopecontent.p: The Mason papers include correspondence, drafts of letters to Andrew Jackson and to Secretary of State John Forsyth; draft of his inaugural address, 1838 and of other messages to the Legislature; topics covered include the Toledo War and the dispute arising from his appointment as Secretary of the Michigan Territory. The Mason papers have been arranged into three series: Correspondence (covering the years 1831-1842); Other papers; and Addresses and messages to the Legislature in the period of 1834 to 1840.

did.unittitle: Lewis Cass to Stevens T. Mason, Washington October 26, 1832

odd.p: (marked "Private." The letter was written in response to letter of Mason's apparently complaining of delay re decision on federal payment of Michigan militia. Cass attempts to salve Mason's feelings and gives a word or two of personal advice)

did.unittitle: Lewis Cass to Governor George B. Porter "or in his absence Stevens T. Mason Secretary of Michigan," Washington October 26, 1832

odd.p: (Written in reply to Porter's [probably] letter of the 24th. Cass says that the Michigan militia recently called up to meet Indian hostilities "will...be recognized as entitled to pay from the United States.")

did.unittitle: Lewis Cass to Stevens T. Mason, Washington October 20, 1834

odd.p: (marked "Private." The letter concerns payment of federal funds to Michigan and the appointment of Mr. Dickerson as factor in Green Bay)

did.unittitle: Lewis Cass to Stevens T. Mason, Washington November 4, 1834

odd.p: (marked "Private." Interesting comments by Cass on President Andrew Jackson's plan to appoint a new governor in Michigan)

did.unittitle: Stevens T. Mason to John Forsyth, United States Secretary of State, Detroit February 20, 1835

odd.p: (Letter concerns Michigan's boundary dispute with Ohio. It sets forth Michigan's claims against Ohio and warns of serious consequences from the actions of Ohio Governor Lucas)

did.unittitle: Stevens T. Mason to General Joseph Brown, Detroit February 28, 1835

odd.p: (Mason instructs Brown to be firm in his attitude toward inhabitants of the disputed territory.)

did.unittitle: Circular from the Executive office in Detroit March 2, 1835

odd.p: (Orders to brigade commanders to prepare for service to Michigan under General Joseph Brown's command)

did.unittitle: Stevens T. Mason to Secretary John Forsyth, Detroit March 6, 1835

odd.p: (Mason notes the action of Ohio to extend jurisdiction over disputed territory and requests federal government's views on the dispute "before the parties in controversy shall proceed to extremities.")

did.unittitle: Stevens T. Mason to General Joseph W. Brown, Detroit March 17, 1835

odd.p: (In reply to Brown's letter, Mason urges caution and suggests strategy for dealing with Ohio's forthcoming attempt to exercise civil functions in the disputed territory. Mason suggests plan to arrest Ohio Governor Lucas after crossing into the disputed territory.)

did.unittitle: Stevens T. Mason to President Andrew Jackson, Detroit March 21, 1835

odd.p: (Mason asks the President to protect Michigan from "the encroachments and usurpations of a powerful neighboring state." He details the activities of Ohio and its governor in the controversy. Mason suggests that U.S. troops proceed to Toledo to keep the peace in that quarter.)

did.unittitle: Stevens T. Mason to Secretary John Forsyth, Detroit March 23, 1835

odd.p: (Letter written in reply to a letter of Forsyth's of March 14th. Mason regrets the President's failure to communicate his wishes (beyond urging forbearance) to Mason in the controversy with Ohio.)

did.unittitle: Stevens T. Mason to Secretary John Forsyth, Detroit March 27, 1835

odd.p: (Letter written in reply to a letter of the 17th from Forsyth. Mason assures Forsyth that Michigan will not hastily resort to force, but again urges that the President make known his views on the controversy.)

did.unittitle: Stevens T. Mason to Secretary Forsyth, Monroe April 2, 1835

odd.p: (Mason says public opinion in Michigan would not accept submission to Ohio, and that if Ohio employs force, Michigan might respond in kind.)

did.unittitle: Stevens T. Mason to Governor Lucas of Ohio, Monroe April 2, 1835

odd.p: (Mason warns Lucas that Michigan will not surrender any of the disputed territory "until the competent tribunal shall have decided the question in controversy," but expresses hope that the dispute will be settled to the satisfaction of both sides.)

did.unittitle: Richard Rush and Benjamin C. Howard to Mason, Monroe April 10, 1835

odd.p: (Letter urges moderation on the part of both Mason and the Ohio authorities with respect to border dispute)

did.unittitle: Stevens T. Mason to Mssrs. Howard and Rush, Commissioners of the President, Monroe April 10, 1835

odd.p: (Mason puts forth Michigan's side of the controversy in some detail, and again asserts Michigan's intention to defend its position.)

did.unittitle: Richard Rush and Benjamin C. Howard to Stevens T. Mason, Toledo April 14, 1835

odd.p: (Letter urging that force not be used by Mason against the Ohio authorities.)

did.unittitle: Stevens T. Mason to Mssrs. Howard and Rush, Detroit April 18, 1835

odd.p: (Mason regrets that he cannot more fully co-operate with the two United States Commissioners.)

did.unittitle: Stevens T. Mason to Lewis Cass, Tecumseh April 25, 1835

odd.p: (Mason informs Cass that Ohio has begun running its claimed boundary line, and he requests immediate federal action to protect "the territory and jurisdiction of the United States.")

did.unittitle: Stevens T. Mason to Secretary Forsyth, Detroit April 29, 1835

odd.p: (Mason urges the Federal government to cease acting merely as mediator and assert the sovereignty of the United States over the disputed territory.)

did.unittitle: Lewis Cass to Stevens T. Mason, "Confidential," Washington May 1, 1835

odd.p: (Cass asks Mason to understand that as a member of the President's cabinet he cannot express his true sentiments as freely as he would like in regard to the dispute between Ohio and his own state of Michigan. He comments upon Jackson's fairness and says that Jackson will act with a "single eye to his duty.")

did.unittitle: Stevens T. Mason to Commissioners Rush and Howard, Monroe May 1, 1835

odd.p: (Mason expresses willingness of Michigan to cooperate with the proper courts in resolving the controversy with Ohio.)

did.unittitle: Stevens T. Mason to Secretary Forsyth, Monroe May 2, 1835

odd.p: (Mason says he is enclosing a copy of his letter to the Commissioners of May 1.)

did.unittitle: Stevens T. Mason to U.S. Commissioners, Monroe May 3, 1835

odd.p: (Mason refuses to consider any solution "short of an exclusive jurisdiction" over the disputed territory.)

did.unittitle: Lewis Cass to Stevens T. Mason, Washington May 9, 1835

odd.p: (Cass admits his own belief that Michigan's claims are correct, but expresses concern lest possible "civil war" erupt between Michigan and Ohio. He says Jackson hopes conflict will be resolved without his interference beyond "advice and remonstrance." Cass advises Mason to "temper the firmness of the community with a due show of moderation.")

did.unittitle: Stevens T. Mason to Secretary Forsyth, Detroit July 11, 1835

odd.p: (Mason says he has convened the Legislature for August 17th and will submit the compromise proposition to the members. Mason recites his determination to remember the rights of the "high minded and patriotic people" of Michigan.)

did.unittitle: Lewis Cass to Stevens T. Mason, Detroit July 11, 1835

odd.p: (Cass offers to come to Monroe if Mason thinks it would be helpful in averting a "collision")

did.unittitle: Stevens T. Mason to Secretary Forsyth, Monroe July 17, 1835

odd.p: (Mason says he is enclosing affidavits pertaining to the wounding of the sheriff in Toledo and urges action lest delay result in further violence.)

did.unittitle: Extract of a letter from Secretary Forsyth to Lewis Cass, Washington July 22, 1835

odd.p: (Forsyth criticizes Mason for not accepting the recommendations of the President in bringing about a temporary arrangement pending final solution of the boundary dispute.)

did.unittitle: Lewis Cass to Stevens T. Mason, Washington August 11, 1835

odd.p: (Cass warns Mason that his failure to coincide with Jackson's policies may bring about his removal by the President.)

scopecontent.p: Photographs in the Mason papers include prints (ca. 1880s) of a portrait of Mason's sister, Emily Virginia Mason, Mason's grave in New York City, and Mason's home in Detroit, Michigan; portrait of Mason's daughter, Dorothea Mason Wright; photograph of painting of Mason (ca. 1830s); and photographs of statue of Mason.
